newsitem.title: SPAIN: Rocket heads for space with Timothy Leary ashes.
newsitem.headline: Rocket heads for space with Timothy Leary ashes.

text.p: The ashes of 1960s LSD guru Timothy Leary and "Star Trek" creator Gene Roddenberry went into space on Monday on board a rocket carrying Spain's first scientific satellite.

The Pegasus rocket was launched from a Lockheed L-1011 jetliner 11,000 metres (36,000 feet) over the Canary Islands, in the Atlantic off North Africa, with observers watching via a satellite link-up from an escort plane.
After the rocket enters space, it will deploy the minisat, the first satellite to be entirely built and designed in Spain.

The cremated remains of Leary, a former Harvard professor who scandalised the U.S. establishment by advocating the use of drugs to the 1960s "flower power" generation and whose final request before dying was for "one last far-out trip", will then go into orbit with those of Roddenberry and 22 other space enthusiasts for the world's first space funeral.
They will remain in orbit attached to the remains of the rocket for anywhere between 18 months and 10 years before they re-enter the atmosphere and burn up.
The satellite will participate in scientific studies, looking at ultraviolet, gravity and low energy gamma rays.
